items.title: [Parse] Don't invalidate compilation condition with invalid platform condition argument
items.body:
```swift
#if arch(x86_64) || arch(ppc64) // Even while "ppc64" is not supported argument ...
   // Code here should be active in x86_64
#endif
```

The issue was introduced in #7955 by me.
It breaks code that should compile. e.g. https://github.com/apple/swift-corelibs-foundation/pull/1026

Scope: optimizations

items.title: [ClangImporter] Honor the 'DC' parameter for importStringLiteral.
items.body:
We don't have any way to import a macro into a different DeclContext anyway, but even then this saves a bit of unnecessary work.

Groundwork for rdar://problem/32199805, which is that upstream Clang has removed a bunch of facilities for going from a SourceLocation or MacroInfo to a Module in favor of things like clang::ModuleMacro.

items.title: [test] Print "Available features" list in ASCIIbetical order.
items.body: I mostly got fed up with the related features like CODEGENERATOR=X being scattered throughout the other unrelated-and-mostly-lowercase features.

items.title: [4.0]Range-info: when checking if a decl reference is contained in the selected range, consider only the start location. rdar://32415952
[4.0] migrator: use the right method to get the location of return type. rdar://32545812
[4.0]RangeInfo: Avoid analyzing orphan kind if the given node list is empty; tentatively fixing rdar://32533734.
[4.0] StdLib documentation revisions
items.body:
This is a cherry pick of #10209.

* Explanation: Revises the documentation for a variety of standard library symbols, including removing the `SeeAlso` tags, which are inconsistent and have limited support.
* Scope: This includes only changes to the standard library's inline documentation.
* Radar/SR: rdar://problem/32749244
* Risk: Very Low
* Testing: The unit and validation test suites.

items.title: runtime: remove an unnecessary helper function to get the class name
[Exclusivity] Make helper functions to static. NFC.
items.body:
Make helper functions static and avoid defining one except when assertions
are enabled.

items.title: Change driver logic for sanitizers support.
items.body:
With this patch different sanitizers (tsan/asan) will be enabled or
disabled on the driver level on a particular OS depending on whether
the required library is present.

The current patch only supports Darwin architectures, but Linux support
should not be hard to add.

items.title: [ClangImporter] Correct curried method types for SE-110.
items.body:
Method types are now required to be `(Self) -> (Args...) -> Return`, not
`Self -> (Args...) -> Return`.

See also https://github.com/apple/swift/pull/9454 .

Fixes rdar://problem/32588152 .

items.title: [4.0] [ClangImporter] Correct curried method types for SE-110.
items.body:
4.0 merge of https://github.com/apple/swift/pull/10233 .

Explanation: Some Objective-C methods would fail to coerce to the expected function types due to behavior with paren types in functions changing with SE-110. This would results in a source-breaking errors with confusing error messages.
Scope: Minor source-breaking regression from 3.1.
Radar: rdar://problem/32588152
Risk: Low: other parts of the compiler do the same thing (e.g. https://github.com/apple/swift/pull/9454 ).
Testing: CI testing.

items.title: [Exclusivity] Relax enforcement for separate struct stored properties
items.body:
Relax the static enforcement of exclusive access so that we no longer diagnose
on accesses to separate stored structs of the same property:

takesInout(&s.f1, &s.f2) // no-warning

And perform the analogous relaxation for tuple elements.

To do this, track for each begin_access the projection path from that
access and record the read and write-like modifications on a per-subpath
basis.

We still warn if the there are conflicting accesses on subpaths where one is
the prefix of another.

This commit leaves the diagnostic text in a not-so-good shape since we refer
to the DescriptiveDeclKind of the access even describing a subpath.

I'll fix that up in a later commit that changes only diagnostic text.

https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-5119
rdar://problem/31909639

Resolves [SR-5119](https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-5119).

items.title: Rdar 32547102 float varargs overflow to gp args area
items.body:
This fixes a bug in swift varargs on x86-64 that shows up when passing more than 8 floats (exhausting the SSE register-save area) but less than 6 non-float GPRs. Formerly the logic incorrectly fell through to storing the remaining floats in unused GP register-save slots of the va_list structure, rather than the overflow arg area, which is where they're supposed to go. It was just missing a condition in the else-if.

fixes rdar://32547102

items.title: Sema: Fix failure to produce diagnostics when 'is' casts are involved
items.body:
When re-typechecking an expression during diagnostics, we begin by
erasing all the types in the expression. However, any expressions
created as part of applying the solution will remain.

CSGen was doing the wrong thing when it encountered EnumIsCaseExpr,
which can only appear in already-type checked ASTs.

Returning expr->getType() is not correct, because the type is not
yet set; returning a null type is intended to signal that a
diagnostic was already emitted, which causes Sema to stop
type checking.

The end result is that certain combinations of invalid code with
an 'is' cast nested inside would crash either the AST verifier
(with asserts on) or in SILGen (with asserts off), because we
would stop trying to diagnose the issue prematurely, and possibly
not emit a diagnostic at all.

Fixes <https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-5050> and
<rdar://problem/32487948>.

items.title: SIL: Use CaptureKind::Box for weak and unowned captures in noescape closures [4.0]
items.body:
* Description: Fixes a bug where a 'weak self' captured by a non-escaping closure could be released too early.

* Origination: Recent regression from #10041.

* Scope of the issue: I suspect this is more common than we think, because people defensively add `[weak self]` to closures.

* Tested: New test added to ensure the right SIL instructions are emitted.

* Reviewed by: @jckarter  

* Radar: <rdar://problem/32718153>.

items.title: Sema: Fix failure to produce diagnostics when 'is' casts are involved [4.0]
items.body:
* Description: Fix a crash-on-invalid where the combination of an 'is' cast inside other invalid code would sometimes cause the type checker to not emit a diagnostic. In a no-assert build this crashes in SILGen, otherwise the AST verifier.

* Scope of the issue: Reported a few times externally, people are hitting this with invalid code.

* Origination: The issue is present in 3.1 also.

* Risk: Very low, this gives more correct behavior to a code path only exercised during diagnostics.

* Tested: New test added to ensure a diagnostic is emitted.

* Reviewed by: @rudkx 

* Radar: rdar://problem/32487948

items.body: The first shot fired in the war against`InOutType`

items.body:
Cherry-pick of #10237 to swift-4.0-branch

fixes rdar://32547102

items.title: Python lint fix for utils/symbolicate-linux-fatal.
items.body: Minor lint fix.

items.title: SILGen: Fix problems with local generic functions
items.body:
When evaluating if a call of a local function requires substitutions,
we checked if the immediate function being referenced captured
generic parameters, without checking if it transitively captured
generic parameters via other local functions it references.

Also, when calling accessors, we did not perform this check at all.

Fix both ordinary function calls and accessor calls to drop the
substitutions only if the *lowered* local captures say it is safe.

Finally, fix Sema to not consider substitutions in local function
references as generic parameter captures, since we now correctly
calculate the transitive closure of all captures.

Fixes <rdar://problem/32761305> and related issues.

items.title: [Parse] Fix skipping string interpolation in Lexer
items.body:
Maintain inner most string literal mode to determine whether we allow
newline character or not.

* Disallow newline after multiline string in string interpolation. ([SR-5171](https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-5171))

  ```swift
  "abc\("""
        defg
        """ // ← This newline should be rejected.
        )hij"
  ```
* Allow unbalanced `"` in multiline string in string interpolation.

  ```swift
  "abc\("""
        "defg ← This unbalanced quote should be accepted
        """)hij"
  ```

items.title: [PrintAsObjC] Silence -Wnullability for the generated declarations.
items.body:
Since Swift 3 and Swift 4 might have different views of an Objective-C API's nullability, we can end up with incompatible overrides, including with inherited initializers. This is unfortunate but also realistic; the Swift 3 code is *not* set up to handle the new nullability used by Swift 4 and Objective-C. Just silence the warning.

(It would be nice to not print inherited initializers at all, but that would mean making sure there are no convenience initializers we have to print as well. Otherwise the class would get mistaken for one without explicit designated initializers.)

rdar://problem/32571301

items.title: [Shepherd] Do stricter checking of -D command line arguments
items.body:
This rebases #6813 and updates a failing test.

Fixes [SR-2404](https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-2404).

items.title: Allow SingleValueContainers to decode collections
items.body:
**What's in this pull request?**
Addresses [SR-5089](https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-5089).

`SingleValueDecondingContainer`s in JSON and Plist previously held the assertion that attempting to decode an array or dictionary from them was a type mismatch (since those represented unkeyed and keyed containers, respectively). This assertion is no longer true, though, since `encode<T : Encodable>(_:)` and `decode<T : Decodable>(_:)` allow you to do just that.

This lifts the assertion and adds unit tests to both implementations to ensure this works.

items.title: Rename some X-Value-related entities
items.body:
* Rename coerceToMaterializableValue to coerceToRValue

* Rename isLValueType to hasLValueType to better match the
intended semantics of the member.

<strike>* Turn on anti-LValue asserts in function types</strike>

The last commit is revertible if we fail any of the test suites.

This patch will be rebased on top of #10242 after it has been merged

items.title: [swift-4.0-branch][stdlib] Resolve the ambiguity for Int32.init(bitPattern:)
items.body:
* Explanation: Int32.init(bitPattern: Float) was introduced as part of integers work, but actually causes an ambiguity when used with literals. This change removes the ambiguity and suggests using Int32(bitPattern: float.bitPattern).
* Scope of Issue: Fixes an ambiguity that was introduced in Beta 1
* Risk: Minimal
* Reviewed By: Mark Lacey
* Testing: Automated test suite + specific test cases
* Directions for QA: N/A
* Radar: <rdar://problem/32768851>

items.title: Collate Codable failure diagnostics
items.body:
**What's in this pull request?**
Codable failures produced diagnostics and notes explaining what failed during synthesis. These diagnostics were being output as they were generated, which was suboptimal because it meant that NOTEs could be produced before the error they were related to.

This was bad for consumers like Xcode, which associate NOTEs with the last error or warning diagnostic. If the only error in produced was a diagnostic from Codable synthesis, the initial NOTEs would be lost in the Xcode UI.

This collates these notes using a diagnostic transaction and only outputs the errors if something actually goes wrong.
